title: Library
description: Elsevier's Dictionary Of Vitamins And Pharmacochemistry [PDF] [28cciucn3nb0]. The dictionary will contain terms covering the following fields and subfields: Vitamin Technology: Vitamin biochemistry ...
text:
The dictionary will contain terms covering the following fields and subfields: Vitamin Technology: Vitamin biochemistry / Physiology; Origin of vitamins: natural, synthetic; Fat-soluble vitamins; Water-soluble vitamins; Vitamins as antioxidants; Vitamin deficiencies / Hypervitaminosis - Enzymes/Proteins: Biotechnology as applied biological science aimed at industrial exploitation - Hormones: Biochemistry; Physiology - Pharmaceutical Chemistry / Pharmaceutical Technology / Pharmaceutical Processes: Conception of the active principles; Structural analysis; Antibiotics and their way of action; Biochemistry; The Drug / The Medicament: Definition, origin, way of action; Biochemistry - Medical Aspects in the languages English, German, French and Portuguese.
This page intentionally left blank
in English, German, French and Portuguese compiled by H.E. PHILIPPSBORN

v Preface A Glance back into the History of Pharmacochemistry. From Antiquity to the Presence. Health has obviously been always one of the main preoccupations of mankind, since its very beginning. The same observation this author made in his Preface to his “Elsevier’s Dictionary of Nutrition and Food Processing”, however, there related to nutrition. As a matter of fact, health and nutrition have always been interrelated, and the wish to cure poor health continues to be one of the basic purposes of humankind, and the desire for restoring good health called for the ways of obtaining it, especially by intake of substances,- which was a logical way to try. The first source and the most lasting one for medicinal substances, for remedies, have been the plants, - has been the vegetable kingdom. Through millenniums the flora furnished prime material to alleviate and to heal diseases, and the Phytotherapy, the treatment by plants, and, later, the active principles obtained from the flora, were the only means medicine had, until the discovery of the atom and thus the development of modern chemistry and molecular biology. Dating from 1300 B.C. approx., the first manuscript informing about phytotherapy, is the “Ebers Papyrus”, discovered by the Egyptologist of this name, in Luxor, city in South Egypt, on the Nile river, on the site of ancient Thebes. This papyrus shows us, that the Egyptians, at the time of Pharaoh Ramses I. (1320–1318 B.C., founder of the 19. Dynasty), already knew medicinal herbs and plants, and they used their knowledge of the vegetable kingdom for medicinal purposes, as e.g. the sea onion, also called: squill, (“Scilla maritima L., Liliaceae”), formerly (already in modern times) used like digitalis today - and purple foxglove has always been the source of the proper digitalis, ("Digitalis purpurea L."), active principle: digitoxin, stimulating heart muscle contraction. - The poppy, ("Papaver somniferum L.", "Papaveraceae") from which unripe capsules the medicamentous substance opium is still obtained. Also we find mentioned cassia i.e. senna leaves (Cassia senna L.; Leguminosae ") still used in form of an extract as a laxative and in cases of colitis; and there we learn, that the fern species called: adiantum, which is “Maidenhair“, (Adiantum pedatum L., Polypodiaceae) was employed for medicinal purposes, having a bitter principle and volatile oil as its consituents. Around 1225 B.C. lived Moses, who led the Israelites out of Egyptian slavery, and in the Pentateuch, - the Five Books Moses - the first five books of Jewish and Christian Scriptures (of the Christian Old Testament) various observations about diseases and also detailed diagnostics, are made, - e.g. on leprosy, [e.g. Leviticus 13.18] the most feared disease of all - which had to wait for ca. 3.000 years for treatment, - the first definite treatment only in our time, in 1935, by the employment of sulphonamides (sulpha drugs), the first medicament against bacteria, discovered by the bacteriologist Gerhard Domagk (1895–1964). The 5th Book Moses, Deuteronomy, observes:
vi “ Jehovah will smite thee with the boil of Egypt, and with the emerods and with the scurvy, and with the itch, whereof thou canst not be healed.“ (ASV – 1901 American Bible Standard Version) Here we find the mentioning of furuncle (boil)- presently to be treated with antibiotics, and scurvy – vitamin C-deficiency disease; the itch we call today also “pruritus” of various origins. In 2 Kings 20.7. of the Old Testament and the Jewish Scriptures, we are told : “And Isaiah said, Take a cake of figs. And they took it and put it on his wound, and he got better.“ (BBE – 1965 Bible in Basic English) Here we have the indication of a diseased part of the body, a wound, and the remedy, a poultice, fomentation of figs, - and we still use a heated/medicated substance e.g. porridge on cloth for application on the skin to ease pain.- We also find indications for the use of phytotherapy, e.g. in Ezekiel 47.12, of the Old Testament and the Jewish Scriptures: “And by the edge of the river..will come up every tree used for food, whose leaves will ever be green. The first will be for food and the leaf will make well those who are ill.” Hippocrates, Greek physician, lived between ca. 460–ca. 377 B.C.. He is considered to be the “father of medicine”– proclaiming that “health is the natural state of men” and the publication of his “Corpus Hippocraticum”, one hundred years after his death, reaffirmed the validity of phytotherapic therapy, the only basis for the elaboration of any type of remedies for still the next 2.300 year to come. Hippocrates subdivided already the medicaments, those for external use, as e.g. poultice, fomentation and oils etc., and solid pills, infusions, wines etc. for oral administration. His “Corpus Hippocraticum“ mentioned already over 230 medicinal herbs and drugs at that epoch. This way, Hippocrates was the founder of Greek medicine and of the Medical School of Cos (in Turkish called: “Istanköy”), a Greek island of the Dodecanese area, in the Aegean See. - Many sages we shall encounter through the centuries to come, searching for ways to heal humankind – often mixing research with myth and magic. At the very beginning of our age, we meet Pliny, Gaius Plinius Secundus, (A.D. 23-79, died at the eruption of the volcano Vesuvius), Roman Scholar, who wrote his Great Natural History (called in German: “große Naturgeschichte”), mentioning a great number of medicinal drugs. During centuries to come, research was based on observation and experiments - based on empiric – on practical experiment. Then came the Middle Ages, a period of European history, beginnig at 476, the Decline of the Roman Empire due to Germanic invasions, until 1453, when occured the conquest of Constantinople, Istanbul, by the Turks - i.e. until the movement of Protestant Reformation in Europe and the discovery of the New World.
vii In ancient times, the Arabs were great contributers in the process of technological and also chemical development. In Minor Asia e.g.,the alchemist Jäbir ibn Hayyän (ca.721– 851), also known as L. Geber, is considered to be the founder of chemistry. In the Middle Ages, Baghdad, turned out to be the centre of Arts and Sciences. The major technological contribuiton of the Arab world, favouring chemistry, was the conception and development of the alembic, the distillation apparatus, being the distillation process, a process of substance-separation, the most important process in chemistry. This was the real “Holy War” the Arab nations fought, against human ignorance, favouring mankind, - all other “holy wars”, they were and they are still fighting, are heresies, as well as the inquisition in Europe (from 1231/32 until the 1859, in Italy) was a disgustful heresy - all these wars and sufferings comitted in the name of religion, because, independently of the name we give the Allmighty, Who is the same for Arabs, Christians and the Jewish people – destruction of men is never holy – but must be considered a religious misguidance, as everyone can be informed, reading his own Scriptures. Within the period of the Middle Ages, we find the Alchemy, an experimental activity with chemical substances, interlaced with magic concepts, thriving for the discovery of universal cure of diseases and for the secrets of prolonging life. The physician Paracelsus (ca. 1493–ca. 1541) was the first to recognize the chemical and physical basis of life, of living organisms. Referring to his experimens with active substances, he said: “The difference between a medicament and a poison lies in the dose”. He must have known it, as he tried them out sometimes, on his own body – a good suggestion for modern physicians to do – before prescribing the drugs for their patients! In this epoch, the era of Renaissance, from the beginning of the 14th century in Italy, until within the 17th century, marked by the beginning of modern science, took place e new method of chemical experiment – the method of systematic experiment, of systematic investigation of Nature, of the Phenomena of Nature. We shall now skip over a couple of years, where many sages did their best in research and experimentation, and we’ll have a rapid look to France, a nation, which contributed greatly with new medicaments and new ideas. Based on opium, occured the development of the “élixir parégorique”, which this author is mentioning, due to the fact, that this French pain-releaving elixir of the past, still is on the market, far away from France, i.e. in Brazil, with the name: “elixir paregórico”, a composite product, containing 0,05 g of opium extract in every 10 g of the total product. Finally came the 19th century, when the French chemist and biologist, Louis Pasteur (1822–1895), one of the most important sages of the 19th century, elaborated the basis of bacteriology, the science of bacteria, the rules of asepsis, trendsetting for the future medicine, the art of curing diseases. He discovered the participation of bacteria in the fermentation process, and he produced, as the first of all researchers, vaccines against e.g. rabies and a series of other diseases. He is considered to be one of the greatest benefactors of humanity.
viii Looking at neighbouring Germany, appeared the Glauber’s salt (as to Johannes Rudolf Glauber, 1604–1668), which is sodium sulphate, still known in Germany as “Glaubersalz” – a cathartic (laxative) and diuretic. We find the physician Samuel Hahnemann (1755–1843) elaborating his fundamental Homoeopathic Law: “Similia similibus curantur” (like cures like), a new conception in medicine, in 1810: When the alchemists used chemistry and magic - homoeopathy substituted magic for mistery: Separating from he mother tincture, portions are submitted to a step-by-step operation of “dynamization”, using the decimal scale, in a ratio of one to nine. This “dynamization” as to homoeopathic ideas, means to minimize the individual dose, creating an infinitesimal dose – increasing simultaneously its therapeutic activity. Consequently, a homoeopathic infinitesimal dose, of a highly concentrated active principle, contains only a very small couple of ca. half a dozen molecules - this is just the same, as to climb up the Sugar Loaf in Rio de Janeiro, enjoying a marvellous view, down, over the city, overlooking the Guanabara Bay and the beaches of the Atlantic Ocean – and pouring a big 1 litre-tumbler, full of pure active principle, into the Ocean waters. The resulting dilution scale is just the same, due to respective calculations. For this reason, e.g., this author and (prospective) patient does not understand homoeopathy under the conception of pharmacodynamics – where there are no molecules – there can’t be any activity – at least no pharmacodynamic one. Rudolf Virchow (1821–1902), pathologist, established the “Zellularpathologie”, the theory, that all diseases are due to pathological alterations of the cells – an “antevision” of the discovery of molecular biology and cytogenetics yet to come. Many years later, the Swiss physician Paul Niehans (1882–1971) also researched the “cellular way“, with his “Frischzellenbehandlung”, treatment with fresh cells, a cellular therapy by injections of living (calf) cells into the human organism – but the cytogenetics, the first results of the study of genetics and cytology - it should take still a long time before they finally arrived! The physician Paul Ehrlich (1854–1915) found in 1906 the first remedy against syphilis - this terrible disease, the first great sexually transmissible disease, devastating humankind since the antiquity - called: “Salvarsan”, an organic arsen compound (Nobel prize 1908). He is the founder of chemotherapy – disease prevention and treatment by active chemical substances. But the employ of arsen compounds, as well as later the bismuth salts, turned out to be difficult in because of their toxic side effects, especially on the liver as well as on blood formation. The definite cure of syphilis had to wait for still another 40 years, when penicilline turned out to be available all over the world. Also the Netherlands made their contribution, an essential one, fundamental for the correct understanding and elaboration of active principles. The chemist Jacobus Henricus van’t Hoff (1852–1911) is the founder of the stereochemistry, and Nobel prize winner of 1901. This research deals with the spatial arrangements of atoms in molecules, the spatial arrangement of atoms in compounds as well as its relation to the properties of the compounds, in our specific case, to the properties of the medicamental active substances. Only knowing the spatial arragement of the atoms we could differentiate between fructose, a fruit sugar and glucose/dextrose, having the same formule C6H12O6. Glucose/dextrose is intolerable for diabetics, fructose may be used in their nutrition as a natural sweetener; isomers, i.e. medicinal compounds with the same
ix number of atoms, but showing differences in structural-spatial arrangements and in properties, can be understood parting from stereochemistry. Brazil, October 31, 1904, Rio de Janeiro, Federal Capital. On the initiative of the physician Osvaldo Cruz (1858–1917) the Brazilian Congress passed a law at this date, turning all citizens bound to undergo vaccination against smallpox, also called “variola”. This vaccine, already known and applied in Europe, based on Louis Pasteur’s research and experiments – was yet unknown in Brazil, at least unknown to the people, who, after all, had to submit themselves to this procedure. With the press campaigning to the contrary, the great statesman and jurist Rui Barbosa proclaimed in the Senate: “The law of vaccination is a dead law!” And he continued – “against the crime, violence and tyranny of the government, which intends to poisen him, with the introduction into his blood of a virus... possible conductor of disease and death”. There was a military rebellion, and on november 10th exploded popular insatisfaction turmoil. The sanitary brigades, accompanied by police, visited house by house, applying the vaccine on the occupants by force. Osvaldo Cruz fought variola successfully and also rescued Rio de Janeiro from yellow fever, turning the city clean, hygienic and receptive to foreign tourists and visitors of the National Exhibition, which would occur, in the shadow of the Sugar Loaf, in the year 1908, presenting to the world an urbanized and beautiful Rio de Janeiro with endless Ocean beaches. At the beginning of the 20th century we encounter other great scientists, like Carlos Chagas, who discovered the Chaga’s disease, (in 1912), caused by a trypanosome (Trypanosoma cruzi) – Gaspar Viana, developing treatment of leishmaniasis, leishmania infection (genus leishmania), flagellate protozoans – and Vital Brazil, dedicated to the research of an antiserum against ophidiasis: poisoning by snake poison. At the beginning of the new century, in the twenties, the United States discovered the elaboration of animal insulin, the hormone, normally produced in the pancreas, by the beta cells of the islets of Langerhans. With this invention, the part of mankind, suffering from diabetes mellitus, got their first medicament to redeem them from their terrible condition. Linus Carl Pauling (1901–1994) introduced the quantum mechanics into chemistry, discovering the principles leading him to determine the nature of chemical bonds and molecular structures, being considered the “father of molecular biology” having also been one of the founders of biotechnology (Winner of the Noble Prize for chemistry in 1954 and for peace in 1962). The British bacteriologist Sir Alexander Fleming (1881–1955) researched in England. Due to Louis Pasteur’s work, the world now new already about bacteria, and Fleming, handling in 1928/29 a bacterial culture, observed that staphylococci are inhibited in their growth by the presence of mould, fungus. So he turned out to be the discoverer of penicillin, an antibiotic acid produced by moulds and used against infections by cocci (spherical bacteria type). He was awarded the Nobel prize in 1945. But his discovery, of enormous importance for saving humankind from infections, was not yet applicable in practice – one of the most important mankind-saving discoveries just remained forgotten for ten years, until 1939, as we shall yet see below.
x In Germany we meet the physician and bacteriologist Gerhard Domagk (1895–1964), who found an active principle against bacteria during his experimentation with azo dyes in 1935: the sulphonamide, the future sulpha drug - first medicament against leprosy and malaria. Only in 1939, the British pathologist, Sir Howard Walter Florey (1898–1968) and the German-born British biochemist Ernst Boris Chain (1906–1979) took up again Fleming’s discovery and isolated in 1940 penicillin G (Benzylpenicillin), parting from cultures of “Penicillium notatum”. The problems of industrial production were resolved during World War II, and then this antibiotic drug, saving humankind from suffering and death, was available, in form of a medicament, the world over – in Europe, with the end of the War, in 1945 only. “Earth bears the basis of life, its produce, the diversity of plants” we said in our “Elsevier’s Dictionary of Nutrition and Food Processing”, and now we go on including also the formation of coal by decomposition of vegetable matter – and the same foodsupplying Flora, guarantee of humankind’s maintenance and growth - is guarantee also for the health of men – directly by Phytotherapy, indirectly by Semisynthesis of Active Principles in biotechnology – and going further back into the primordial structure of our organism – by way of molecular biology, by cytogenetics, showing the ultimate biologic organizational facts of our organism, on molecular basis, showing us that all the life is based on the macromolecule called DNA – starting from the chromosomes and the genes, the genetic cell material – to the final genetic phenomena of life – we realize that: This intimate understanding turned phytotherapic medicaments, as well as coalchemistry derivated active substances, more targeted in its applications.
xi The Epoch of Vitamins. Vitamins are no definite chemical group of compounds. The designation “vitamin” is considered to be a functional one and was created by Casimir Funk in 1911, believing that the antiberiberi factor of the vitamin B-complex, thiamine, was an amine essential for life or “vita” – but as not all vitamins turned out to be amines, continued the designation without the final “e”. Great plagues in ancient times, until the passed century, were deficiency-diseases, linked to certain vitamins. The most important diseases were scurvy, a vitamin Edeficiency disease, beriberi, based on poor nutrition, due to lack of vitamin B1 (thiamin), and the rickets, a children’s disease, affecting the bones, due to hypovitaminosis D. The assimilation of calcium and phosphorus is favoured by sunlight and is necessary to avoid this disease – but sunlight is rare in Northern Europe, especially in the winter months. Nutritional supplementation of vitamin D prevents this horrible problem of bone malformation. But people didn’t know about it in the middle of the 1600s, when occurred an increase of rickets, in an epoch, when people migrated to the cities, spending less time in the few sunshine on the fields, and this turned out to be a tendency, accompanying the industrial development and the industrial revolution. Beriberi is a nutritional deficiency disease, causing degeneration of the digestive and nervous system, and of the heart. We have a report from the Japanese Navy, of the year 1882, when half of the crew, along a cruise of nine months, suffered from this deficiency disease. Their nutrition had been polished rice. Brazil started a great project in 1872, and its execution lasted until 1912: The – tragic – epic in the rain florest, the construction of the railway Madeira-Marmoré, in the northern State of Rondônia. The Brazilian Emperor, Dom Pedro II, favoured this railway for the transport of caoutchouc, produced in the State of Amazonas, to Bolivia. Two US construction companies failed, due to the “florest demons” as there were plenty of them: The hot and humid tropical forest climate with malaria, yellow fever, and Indians with their unerring bows and arrows. But there was still a greater and yet unknown enemie when the project was started again in 1903: the beriberi. Officially, thirty thousand workers died during the construction of the railway; but it goes, that with each sleeper layed, one man died, and the railway, from Porto Velho to GuajaráMirim had to run 366 km, that means 549 thousand of sleepers to keep the railroad rails in place! Well, exaggeration, but we know, that when the physician Walcott was nominated to direct the Medical Services of the Railway Madeira-Marmoré, there had been nearly 1000 cases of beriberi in the previous four years. He ordered the hospital to include fresh meat, eggs and other types of fresh foodstuffs into the diet – the men in the hospital got rapidly rid of the disease, whereas outside – the workers on their customary nutrition as beans, macaroni, codfish and biscuits - the devastating beriberi continued. Only the researches of vitamin B1 (thiamine), by R.R. Williams, together with other constituents of the vitamin B complex, like nicotinic acid and nicotinamide, (this one discovered by Spies in 1937) furnished the cure of beriberi and pellagra (this a scaly dermatitis , gastrointestinal disorders and depression).
xii In Northern Brazil, children today still suffer e.g. from vitamin A deficiency, due to extremely poor nutrition or, better, absence of it. Vitamin A is important for the vision. It forms the purple pigment rhodopsin, the photorecpetor in the rod cells of the retina. Hypovitaminosis A causes xerophthalmia, a progressive eye disease, resulting ultimately in blindness. This problem can be resolved by vitamin A- or provitamin Asupply, e.g. in school nutrition, or added into basic nutritional ingredients, as meal and sugar. The lack of vitamins, and especially the deficiency of vitamin C, decided, in ancient epochs, the interruption of wars, the outcome of belligerent activities. In Egypt and from Greece to Rome - people suffered from scurvy - the crusaders of the expeditions, formed by the Christian Church, to win back the Holy Land (eight cruzades, from 1095 to 1270) had to suffer and to die from scurvy - and in the Middle Ages it was endemic in the Northern Europe winter - this hypovitaminosis ended prematurely voyages and cruises, interrupted projects of circumnavigations, killing the crews, disabling the seafarer; and it made no difference between circumnavigators and corsairs, merchant fleets and pirates. Nobody knew why all those people were falling ill. And the cause of all this was the lack of fresh vegetables, of fruits as nutrition on long voyages. During Vasco da Gama’s (1468–1524)voyage in 1493, discoverer of the sea route to the East Indies, he lost 100 sailors of his crew of 160 – all of them dying from scurvy. We find an observation on behalf, from the 16th century, when in 1535/36 Jacques Cartier wrote about what we now know to be scurvy - that, following some good advice of the Newfoundland Indians – he nourished his crew on a preparation made of fir needles, with the purpose of curing them from an epidemic, and it seems, he was successful. Written down by a French seafarer in the 18th century, Bernadin de Saint-Pierre, we are told this frightening incident: “During the first month on sea, we immersed the first body, somewhere alongside of Africa; passing through the Cape (of Good Hope) we had 21 sick men on board; at the fourth month on sea, 45 were sick.” and so he went on, three days later, there were already 60 cases of what we now know to be hypovitaminosis, and he finished then: “happily we finally arrived!”. Well, we don’t know, whether he had a vague vision, that eating fresh vegetables would avoid this kind of problem, if he had had, then he indeed has not been very “saint”, as he, himself, preferred fresh vegetables all the way long, keeping himself in good health to present us with this interesting report. In all these cases the seafarer described the consequences of the same disease, consequences of vitamin C-deficiency, the consequences of scurvy. Luiz Vaz de Camões, (1424/25-1580), Portuguese poet, he himself on the ship, observed closely the devastating consequences of scurvy, transmitting us in his epic “Os Lusíadas , (Canto V, 81/82) in poetic form: “ – ali lhe incharam As gengivas na boca, que crescia A carne, e juntamente apodrecia!
xiii Apodrecia c’um fétido e bruto Cheiro, que o ar vizinho inficionava.“ And this means, in less poetic form, but exact, referring to the “bruto”, i. e. coarse intonation: “There the gums swell in their mouth where the flesh grew and together decayed! Decayed with a stinking and brutish Smell, infecting the neighbouring air.” Vitamin C, i.e. ascorbic acid, was isolated around the year 1921 and it was synthesized only in 1933. And that event meant to be the end of scurvy, the end of thousands of years of suffering and death for humankind. It is ours to see, what the future will bring! Looking back into the past, to Rudolf Virchow and his “Zellularpathologie” and thus to the understanding of cytopathogenicity, at the beginning of the 20th century and to Paul Niehans, with his “Frischzellenbehandlung”, direct treatment with fresh cells, in the middle of the past century – to the present days and perspectives – we reach now the molecular biology and cytogenetics – the first one, researching the molecules associated to the living organism, the protein synthesis, the structure of nucleic acids – the physicochemical foundation of our life; and the second branch, the association between cytology and genetics, the functioning of cell life and the genetic phenomena, as the manifestation of variations in the living organisms, the final understanding of the human genome – the totality of human genetic material – the understanding of cytodifferentiation, i. e. the development of undifferentiated cells into specialized ones to “repair” neurological or endocrinal functions or even harmed organs, to recreate diseased body parts, the complete understanding of the process of therapeutic cloning, i.e the application of cloning in medical research, also research of embryonic stem cells – this will show us the new pathway to a new kind of “medicine” – turning away from the coal-chemistry active principals, which are the basis of medicaments of today, to the revelation of what we could call: - Healing Life by Life itself. And going back in human life, back on the way of biological evolution, back to primeval times – we could accompany the thoughts of the Greek philosopher Thales of Miletus (ca. 625–547 B.C.), who proclaimed that: “Water is the origin of all things.” Henry Erwin Philippsborn, January 2007
xiv Vitamins in Scheme Vitamin Technology, Pharmacochemistry Vitamins/Pharmaceutical Technology //Pharmaceutical Forms Vit.: Vitamins. Definition: Organic substances, necessary for the good functioning of metabolic processes of the organism, furnished by nutrition, acting as coenzymes and precursors of coenzymes. Vitamin Technology: Vitamin Biochemistry/Physiology. Origin of Vitamins : natural, synthetic. Fat-soluble Vitamins. Water-soluble Vitamins. Vitamins as Antioxidants. Hypovitaminosis (Vitamin Deficiencies )/ Hypervitaminosis. Prod.: Production Terms. Pharmaceutical Chemistry/Pharmaceutical Technology/Pharmaceutical Processes The Medicamentous Forms. The Active Principle. The Origin of the Active Principle. Chemical Processes Pharm.: Pharmacodynamics/Pharmacokinetics. The activity of medicaments on the human organism. Interaction of a drug. Enz.: Enzymology. Protein: Organic compounds, containing carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, sulphur etc.; enzymes, hormones, immunoglobulins. Enzyme: Proteic substance which catalyzes and promotes a specific biochemical reaction. Cyt.: Cytogenetics. Cytology. Genetics/Chromosomes. Mol.: Molecular Biology. Phenomenas of the molecular basis of cell structure, cell functioning and cell activity. Atoms. Molecules. Horm.: Hormones. Definition: A gland product circulating in body fluid and having a stimulatory effect on cellular activity.
xv Hormone Biochemistry. Hormone Physiology. Ant.: Antibiotics. Definition: Chemical substance produced synthetically or by microorganisms, which inhibits the growth of and/or destroys other microorganisms. Phyto.: Phytotherapy. Definition : Use of medicamentous active principles, of plant origin, in therapy. Plants. Medicinal Herbs. Medicamentous Active Principles. Anat.: Anatomy. The living human organism. Homoeop.: Homoeopathic Notions. Samuel Hahnemann: “Like cures like” Med.: Medical Aspects. Physiology Miscellany
xvi Die Technologie der Vitamine, Die Pharmacochemie Vitamine/Pharmazeutische Technologie/Pharmazeutische Formen Vit.: Vitamine Begriffsbestimmung Organische Substanz, durch die Ernährung zugeführt, notwendig für das gute Funktionieren metabolischer Prozesse des Organismus, welche als Coenzym oder Vorläufer des Coenzyms wirkt : Vitamine in der Technologie: Biochemie der Vitamine/Physiologie. Ursprung der Vitamine : natürlicher; synthetischer. Fettlösliche Vitamine. Wasserlösliche Vitamine. Vitamine als Antioxydantien. Hypovitaminose (Vitamin-Mangel)/Hypervitaminose. Prod.: Fachausdrücke aus der Produktion. Pharmazeutische Chemie/Pharmazeutische Technologie/Pharmazeutische Prozesse. Die medikamentösen Formen. Der Wirkstoff. Der Ursprung des Wirkstoffes. Pharm.: Pharmakodynamik / Pharmacokinetik. Die Wirkung der Arzneistoffe auf den menschlichen Organismus. Interaktion eines Arzneimittels. Enz.: Die Enzymologie. Protein: Organische Verbindungen, welche Kohlenstoff, Wasserstoff, Stickstoff Sauerstoff und Schwefel usw. enthalten; Enzyme, Hormone, Immunoglobuline. Enzym: Protein-Substanz, welche eine spezifische biochemische Reaktion katalysiert und fördert. Cyt.: Zytogenetik. Zytologie. Genetik/Chromosomen. Mol.: Molekularbiologie. Phänomene der molekularen Grundlage des Aufbaus der Zelle, ihres Funktionierens und ihrer Aktivität. Atome. Moleküle. Horm.: Hormone. Begriffsbestimmung: Eine Drüsensubstanz, welche in den Körpersäften zirkuliert und eine anregende Wirkung auf die Zellaktivität ausübt.
xvii Biochemie der Hormone. Physiologie der Hormone. Ant.: Antibiotika. Begriffsbestimmung: Synthetisch oder von Mikroorganismen produzierte chemische Substanz, welche das Wachstum anderer Mikroorganismen hemmt und/oder zerstört. Phyto.: Phytotherapie. Begriffsbestimmung: Einsatz, in der Therapie, von medikamentösen Wirkstoffen pflanzlichen Ursprungs. Pflanzen. Heilkräuter. Medikamentöser Wirkstoff. Anat.: Anatomie. Der lebende menschliche Organismus. Homoeop.: Begriffe der Homöopathie. Samuel Hahnemann: “Gleiches wird durch Gleiches geheilt”. Med.: Medizinische Aspekte. Physiologie. Verschiedenes.
xviii La Technologie des Vitamines, La Pharmacochimie Vitamines/Technologie Pharmaceutique/Formes Pharmaceutiques Vit. : Vitamines. Définition: Substances organiques indispensables au bonne fonctionnement des processus métaboliques de l’organisme, apportées par la nutrition, agissant comme des coenzymes et des précurseurs de coenzymes. La Technologie des Vitamines Biochimie des Vitamines/Physiologie. Origine des Vitamines: naturelle, synthétique. Vitamines liposolubles. Vitamines hidrosolubles. Vitamines comme des Antioxydants. Hypovitaminoses (Carences vitaminiques); Hypervitaminoses Prod.: Termes de la Production. Chimie Pharmaceutique/Technologie Pharmaceutique/Processus Pharmaceutiques Les Formes Medicamenteuses. Le Principe Actif. L’Origine du Principe Actif. Pharm.: Pharmacodynamie/Pharmacocinétique L’activité des médicaments sur l’organisme humain. Interaction d’un médicament. Enz.: Enzymologie. Protéine: Composé organique, contenant du carbone, d’hydrogène, de l’oxygène, du soufre etc.; enzymes, hormones, immunoglobulines. Enzyme: Substance protéique catalysant et stimulant des réactions biochimiques spécifiques. Cyt.: Cytogénétique. Génétique/Chromosomes. Mol.: Biologie Moléculaire Phénomènes de la base moléculaire de la structure des cellules, de leur fonctionnement et activité. Atomes. Molécules. Horm.: Hormones. Définition: Substance glandulaire, qui circule dans les liquides organiques en produisant un effet stimulant sur l’activité cellulaire. Biochimie des Hormones. Physiologie des Hormones.
xix Ant. : Antibiotiques. Définition. : Substance chimique produite synthétiquement ou par des micro-organisms, qui inhibe la croissance et/ou détruit les autres micro-organisms. Phyto. : Phytothérapie Définition: Usage des principes actifs médicamenteux de l’origine végétale dans des thérapies. Les plantes. Les herbes médicinales. Principes actifs médicamenteux. Anat.: Anatomie. L’organisme humain vivant. Homoeop.: Notions de la Homéopathie. Samuel Hahnemann: “similitude guérit similitude.” Med. : Les Aspects Médicamenteux. Physiologie. Questions diverses.
xx A Técnologia das Vitaminas, a Farmacoquímica Vitaminas/Tecnologia Farmacêutica/Formas Farmacêuticas Vit.: Vitaminas. Definição: Substância orgânica, necessária para o bom funcionamento dos processos metabólicos do organismo, fornecida pela nutrição, agindo como coenzima e precursor de coenzimas. Tecnologia das Vitaminas. Bioquímica das Vitaminas/Fisiologia. Origem das Vitaminas : natural, sintético. Vitaminas lipossolúveis. Vitaminas hidrossolúveis. Vitaminas como Antioxidantes. Hipovitaminoses (Deficiências Vitamínicas)/Hipervitaminoses. Prod.: Termos da Produção. Química Farmacêutica/Tecnologia Farmacêutica/Processos Farmacêuticos As Formas Medicamentosas O Princípio Ativo. A Origem do Princípio Ativo. Pharm.: Farmacodinâmica / Farmacocinética A Ação dos Medicamentos no Organismo Humano A Interação da Droga medicamentosa. Enz.: Enzimologia. Proteína: Composto orgânico, contendo carbono, nitrogênio, oxigênio, enxofre etc.; enzimas, hormônios, imunoglobulinas. Enzima: Substância protéica que catalisa e promove uma reação bioquímica especial. Cyt.: Citogenética. Citologia. Genética /Cromossomos. Mol.: Biologia Molecular: Fenômenos da Base molecular da Estrutura das Células, do Funcionamento e da Atividade cellular. Átomos. Moléculas Horm.: Hormônios. Definição: substância glandular, que circula nos fluídos corporais atuando com um efeito estimulante sobre a atividade celular. Bioquímica dos Hormônios.
xxi Fisiologia dos Hormônios. Ant.: Antibióticos. Definição: Substância química sinteticamente produzida ou produzida por microorganismus, a qual inibe/ou destrói o crescimento de outros microorganismus. Phyto.: Fitoterapia. Definição: Emprego, em Terapias, de Princípios Medicamentosos Ativos de Origem Vegetal. Plantas. Ervas Medicinais. Princípio Ativo Medicamentoso. Anat.: Anatomia O Organismo Humano vivo. Noções da Homeopatia. Samuel Hahnemann: “Semelhantes curam-se pelos Semelhantes”. Med.: Aspectos Médicos. Fisiologia. Anatomia.

mpl masculine plural
n

neuter
pl plural
m/f masculine or feminine m/n masculine or neuter
3. The symbol v designates a verb. 4. The abbreviation adj designates an adjective. 5. The abbreviation adv designates an adverb. 6. Synonyms and abbreviations are separated by semicolons. 7. Two kinds of brackets are used: [ ] the information can be either included or left out; ( ) the information does not form an integral part of the expression, but helps to clarify it.
